listWit.witness: London, British Museum Royal 10 A I

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: File Started for the first time.

div.head: Concerning the text
div.p:
Again it is asked Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 1, n. 1
etc. after the Master determined about the generation of the Son and the procession of the Holy Spirit, now he treats about each of them individually by comparison, and he divides this into two parts because in the first place he inquires about the order of procession, in the second place he shows the difference between generation and spiration. The second part begins at the beginning of distinction 13, at
after these things Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 1, n. 1
etc.

The first part is divided into two because in the first place he introduces the questions, in the second place he puts responses to these. The second begins at
these things and questions of this type Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 1 [n. 2] . And this is divided into three because in the first place he shows that the Holy Spirit does not proceed from the Father earlier than the Son, in the second place that he does not proceed more fully from one than the other, in the third place he explains the understanding of some authorities in a different sense. The second begins at
but now it should be treated Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 2 [n. 1] . The third begins at
Augustine nevertheless Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 2 [n. 2] .

Then follows distinction 13
after this Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 1, n. 1
etc., which is divided into two parts because in the first place he shows in what mode the Spirit is not able to be said to be begotten, in the second place in what sense it is not able to be said to be unbegotten. The second begins at
now it should be considered Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 4, n. 1 . The first part is divided in three because in the first place he shows how to be generated does not suit the Holy Spirit, in the second place that to proceed applies to the Son, in the third place that between generation and procession there is a difference or distinction. The second starts
But when the Holy Spirit Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 2, [n. 1] . But the third starts at
among the generation of the Son Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 3, n. 1 . The second principal part is divided into three because in the first place he shows that the Holy Spirit ought not to be called begotten, in the second place from the words of Jerome he makes an objection to the contrary, and in the third place he solves the argument of the objection. The second begins at
nevertheless Jerome Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 4, n. 5 . And the third at
but as this Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 4, n. 7
etc. And this is the division of these distinctions, etc.

Whether it is possible that the Holy Spirit was produced is neither begotten nor unbegotten, whether the Holy Spirit proceeds from the Father and Son in such a way that faith concedes that it is neither unbegotten or begotten, whether the Holy Spirit is produced in such a way from the Father and the Son that he is neither begotten nor unbegotten.

It truly seems that this is not the case because, if the Holy Spirit were not begotten, it would follow that the pilgrim theologian would be able to know the difference or the distinction between generation and procession. The consequence is valid and the falsity of the consequent is clear through
Augustine
and the Master in the text of his 13th distinction saying:
between generation and procession, while we live here, we are not able to distinguish Lombard, I, d. 13, c. 3, n. 1 .

In the second place, the internal productions of the divine are of the same reasons and species, therefore just as the Son through one is said to be begotten, so the Holy Spirit for a similarity in species is able to be called begotten. The consequence is clear because specific identity of production and of producing and the produced terms argue sufficiently for the identity of the denomination or of the natural properties, otherwise it would be the case that the production of Socrates and Plato would be of the same species, and nevertheless one would be of the same species and the other would not. The antecedent is first proved because the terms or persons produced through these productions do not differ in species, but only numerically or personally.

In the third place, the Holy Spirit is and is not begotten, therefore it is unbegotten, The consequence is clear because the negative
infers one affirmative about a negated predicate and a proposition about negated predicate infers one about an infinite or infinitated predicate, therefore etc.

In opposition is the
Master in this distinction 13
Lombardus, I, d. 13, XXX
and
Augustine, in book 1 De Trinitate, chapter 6
Augustinus, De Trinitate, I, XXX .

The first conclusion: though it is impossible that the production of the Son is not distinguished from the production of the Holy Spirit, nevertheless from the common law in the present life no one is able to know this distinction with evident reason. The first is proved because otherwise it would be possible that there is in the divine which now de facto is, if these productions were not distinguished. But this is impossible, therefore. The impossibility is clear through what is said above because in whatever way the divine is internally, it is necessarily that way. The second part is clear through the
Master, in this distinction XXX . Again through Augustine XIII De Trinitate, chapter 13 saying that
we will see the Trinity in this light where no reason will be Augustinus, De Trinitate, XIII, c. 13, xxx . And the entire conclusion confirmed through
Damascene, in book 1, chapter 10
saying
in someway we say there is a difference between generation and procession Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa, I, c. 10 . But what mode of difference this is are in no way for this and also the conclusion words in the text of the Master. .

The first corollary: in which
it does not follow evidently that the the Son is produced only by the Father and that the Holy Spirit is produced by both, therefore the generation of the Son is distinguished from the procession of the Holy Spirit. This is clear because the unity or plurality of the one's producing does not imply the plurality or distinction of the productions, most especially where there is one mode of acting, as is the case in what has been proposed, as it was said above.

The second corollary: that in the same way it does not follow, produced supposites are plurified distinctly, therefore the productions of the same are in some way distinguished. This is clear from the same.

Third corollary: that from the mode of producing such a distinct is not able to be evidently shown. This is clear because, if the mode of proceeding sufficed, then this would be, therefore because the Son proceeds as born and the Holy Spirit as given, as says
Augustine V De Trinitate, chapter 14 . But this argument does not show why the Holy Spirit does not proceed as born, therefore it does not suffice. From what has been said it would be able to be inferred that something is a necessary being which no pilgrim under the current law is able to know. This is clear from the distinction of the production of the persons.

Second conclusion: a specific distinction between the divine persons is as repugnant as the same distinction between eternal productions. This is proved because it is repugnant in both cases, therefore it is equally repugnant. The consequences is clear because the repugnance or the opposition of a contradiction does not have latitude nor can it be more or less when taken in the same way. The antecedent is proved because every specific distinction argues and implies diversity of nature. But such diversity is repugnant to the divine essence, therefore a specific distinction in the divine persons or productions should not be asserted. The second part is proved because productions are not distinct unless by reason of a distinction of the persons or because it terminates in distinct persons. But the persons are not distinguished in species but only in number, therefore. In the second place, the conclusion is proved because the divine supposites are absolutely of the same perfection, therefore they are of the same species. The consequence holds because, just as no two species are of the same perfection, so etc. The antecedent is catholic. In the third place, it is confirmed through Damascene, in book III, chapter 6
saying:
we say the hypostases differ in number and not in species or in nature Damascenus, XXX , therefore.

The first corollary: but the divine supposites and internal productions are not distinguished specifically, it is conceded catholically that they are distinguished in number. This is clear through what has been said.

Second corollary: it does not follow a is produced through generation and b is not produced through generation, therefore a is specifically distinguished from b. This is clear because the Son and Holy Spirit are not distinguished specifically, and nevertheless the Son is generated and the Holy Spirit is not.

Third corollary: though in the divine there are three supposites distinct in number, nevertheless they are not properly called three individuals of the same species, This corollary is asserted by
Thomas of Argentina, in book 1, distinction 12?
Thomas of Strasbourg, XXX
saying it is not able to be because individual conveys a difference of nature, but not a supposite.

Third conclusion: just it is not the case that the Holy Spirit is the Father or the Son, so it is repugnant that the Holy Spirit is begotten or not begotten. The first part is proved because the divine persons are necessarily distinguished, therefore. The consequence is clear and the antecedent is proved because, if it were not, there would be a confusion of persons in the divine or there would only be one, each is an error and impossible, therefore. The second part is proved because to be begotten is to be the Son and to be unbegotten is to be the Father, therefore etc. The antecedent is clear in distinction 13 in distinction 13 where he says that
if the Holy Spirit were begotten, there would be two sons in the divine, and if he were unbegotten, we would put two fathers in the trinity Augustinus, Ad Orosium, q. 2 (PL 40:734) Cf. Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 13, c. 4 [n. 3] , just as Augustine says, therefore.

The first corollary: just as the alterity of persons is through natural identity, so the duality of the productions is through triune personality. This is proved because in the divine there are only two productions, namely generation and procession.

The second corollary: just as the Father alone is produced by nothing, so the Father alone is properly called unbegotten. This is clear through what has been said. Again through the
Damascene, in book one, chapter nine , saying
only the Father is unbegotten, only the Son is begotten, only the Holy Spirit is processible or proceeding. Damescenus, De Fide Orthodoxa, I, c. 9 .

Third corollary: though the Holy Spirit is able to be called unbegotten improperly and negatively,
nevertheless it ought not to be called unbegotten properly or privitively. The first part is clear because the Holy Spirit is not begotten, therefore it is unbegotten, when understanding unbegotten negatively. The second part is clear through what has been said because then the person of the Holy Spirit would be the person of the Father, which is impossible. From everything else the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

Against the first conclusion, it is argued in the first place with the arguments of
Hugolinus against Gregory arguing in the first book, in distinction 10 up to distinction 14 Hugolinus, XXX
because the Son is from one, the Holy Spirit from two, therefore from the mode of proceeding between generation and procession there is able to be a distinction. But Master Gregory says that this does not suffice, therefore Hugolinus replies in opposition where there is production of the Word a double producing or productive thing is not required, therefore the ratio of distinction between generation and procession is able to be assigned. The antecedent is clear because one producing thing is sufficient.

In the second place, where there is generation of a living person, there is not able to be several generating, unless one of them were disposed in the mode of a mother, but this is impossible in the divine, therefore.

In the third place, where a person is necessary and it speaks itself, if another person is required, it follows either that it is not necessary or produces in another mode than by speaking, therefore.

In the fourth place against the third corollary, since, though the Holy Spirit is knowledge, nevertheless it is not knowledge through process, nor is the Son love by generation. Therefore these productions are sufficiently distinguished given that the Son is not love through generation and nor does the Holy Spirit have what is knowledge through spiration. See
Hugolinus, book I, distinction 10 and 11, article 4
Hugolinus, I, d. 10 et 11, a. 4 , where he argues against Gregory.

In the fifth place, ever perfect operation terminates in some produced terminus. But it possible to conclude by reason that in God there is the perfect operation of intellect and will, therefore it is possible to conclude that divine understanding terminates int he Word and the divine will terminates in love. But when nothing produces itself, it follows that what is produced really differs from what is producing. But such a difference is not able to be in the essence, therefore it must be in the persons and their processions.

In the sixth place, that created nature is found in many supposites is a type of perfection in creatures absolutely, therefore it should be attributed to the divine nature. The consequence holds because whatever is a kind of perfection in creatures ought to be attributed to God.

Against the second conclusion, the production of divine persons is according forms distinct in species, therefore such productions are distinguished in species. The consequence is clear because a distinction is specific which is according to distinct forms. And the antecedent is clear because divine relations are distinct in species, namely paternity, filiation, and passive spiration, and through things the divine supposites are distinguished, therefore.

In the second place, the divine supposites, having been made distinct through these things, are not able to give a distinction other than this which suits them according to their formal ratio. But paternity and filiation differ in species according to their formal rationes, therefore these things which make them distinct are distinguished in species.

In the third place against the corollaries, in the three divine persons there is not a greater goodness than in one, therefore three persons are posited in vain, therefore this should not be posited. This consequence is clear because
God and nature do nothing in vain
Aristoteles, De caelo, I (XXX)
as is said in
book I On the heavens , and the antecedent is catholic.

In the fourth place, just as the highest good is disposed to evil, so the highest one is disposed to a multitude. But it is repugnant for there to be evil in the highest good, therefore it is repugnant for there to be a multitude in the highest one. Therefore, just as sin or the ability to sin is repugnant to God, so is a plurality of persons.

In the fifth place, every relative real opposition goes out to two extremes which are really distinguished. Therefore either it is necessary to posit one relative opposition in the divine or two. If one, then there will only be two extremes, If two, then there will be four extremes, and as a consequence there will be four persons, which should not be said.

In the sixth place, it is the same thing to say the Father speaks himself as it is to say he generates the Word. But the Son and the Holy Spirit perfectly speak themselves or understand just as the Father, therefore either three words are said or none.

In the seventh place, the Father by loving the Son, and the Son by loving the Father back produce the Holy Spirit. But the Father does not love the Holy Spirit less than the Son, nor is loved less in return by the Holy Spirit than by the Son, therefore the Father and the Holy Spirit produce another Holy Spirit or
no person is produced through love.

Against the third conclusion and corollaries, it is argued in the first place through Jerome who is quoted by the
Master in distinction 11
Lombard, Sent. I, d. 13, c. 4 [n. 5]
, saying
The Holy Spirit is not the Father, but is unbegotten, nevertheless he is not the Father because he is of the Father Hieronymus, Regulis definitionum, XXX , therefore the Holy Spirit is unbegotten.

Against the first corollary, there is a single mode of communicating nature, as says the Commentator VIII of the Physics . But through some internal production nature is communicated, therefore there will only be one production.

In the third place, between the generation and the procession there is no relative opposition, therefore there is no distinction. The consequence holds because all things are the same where there is no opposition of relation. And the antecedent is proved because everything that is generated proceeds although the converse is not true, therefore.

Ad primum, negatur assumptum universaliter quia verbum mentis nostrae secundum esse procedit tam a mente quam ab obiecto. Secundo, dico quod supposito quod unum producens sit sufficiens, si tamen sunt duo, non minus procedit verbum.

Ad secundum, posset negari antecedens universaliter suppositum quia non quilibet modus generationis omnium viventium est notus nobis. Secundo dico quod solum illa habet veritatem in his quae materialiter ad generationem producti concurrunt, et sic non est de Patre et Filio respectu Spiritus Sancti quia aequaliter spirant Spiritum Sanctum. Tertio, ratio reducitur contra facientem in nullam productione viventis ex vivente possunt esse pluries producentes nisi unus sit, etc. Sed productio Spiritus Sancti est productio viventis ex vivente, ergo Filius se habet loco matris[?]

Ad tertium, dicitur quod antecedens non habet maiorem veritatem de dre[?] quam de diligere, constat enim quod Pater se diligendo est opus, et tamen requiritur Filius qui se diligat ad productionem Spiritus Sancti.
Secundo, dicitur quod una persona divina non proprie requirit aliam prout hoc verbum sonat indigentiam et imperfectionem.

Tertio, dico quod secundum eum met, consequentia non valet ad productionem b requiruntur pluries personae, ergo neutra est opus nam distinctione 7a[?] dici hanc consequentiam non valere a[?] est tantae potentiae quod sufficit solus producere b et a solus non potest producere creaturam d, igitur maior potentia requiritur ad producendum d quam b.

Ad quartum, dicitur quod ratio petit principium quia cum Spiritus Sanctus procedat et eadem natura per processionem utrique aeque communicatur perfecte quare est quod una productio non est alia dre[?] ergo quod Filius non sit amore per generationem, etc. est manifestare idem per idem vel magis notum per minus.

Ad aliud diceret[?] adversarius quod illud non habet veritatem in operationibus immanentibus sicut sunt velle et intelligere ad intra unde IX Metaphysciae et I Physicorum dicitur quod
vel
vel
operationes immanentes nihil constituitur, aliter aeque probaretur quod Spiritus Sanctus produceret adintra.
Ad sextum, negatur antecedens quia natura spiritualis non multiplicata in pluribus suppositis est perfectior quam ista materialia et corruptibilia[?] quae multiplicatur per individua supposita.

Ad primum contra secundam conclusionem, primo negatur antecedens quia, sicut Pater non distinguitur specie a Filio, sic nec Filio a paternitate quia Filio et Filius sunt idem. Secundo posset dici quod dato quod paternitas et filiatio
non
distinguerentur specifice conside?te[?] secundum se tamen ut constituunt divina supposita habent modum proprietatum individualium, sed quia non dico personas constitui per illas proprietates, ideo sto in prima solutione et dimitto secundam quam est Thomae de Argentis.
Ad secundam, dicitur quod maior non habet veritatem de his quae dant esse individuale et incommunicabile sicut hic, sed tenet de principiis divinis quae distinctis per ipsam dant esse simpliciter.
Ad tertium, negatur consequentia quia illa bonitas pluribus modis est ibi.

Ad quartum, transeat maior sed cum ultra dicitur quod Deo vel
essentiae divinae quae sic est summe bona repugnat tam plurificari quam peccare dampnari conceditur, sed tamen cum ipsius unitate stat bene personarum pluralitas.

Ad quintum, dicitur quod in divinis sunt tamtum duo relationes oppositae. Ex prima habemus
habere
Patrem et Filium. Ex secunda Spiritum Sanctum quia alterum extremorum duae relationis non constituit personam, scilicet spiratio activa quae communis est Patri et Filio.

Ad sextum dicitur quod, licet non possit ratio evidens assignari seclusa fide quare dicere vel intelligere Filii non terminatur ad aliquem terminum productum, tamen supposita fide potest dici quod dicere potest dupliciter sumi. Uno modo proprie prout idem est quod verbum concipere, et sic sumit
Augustinus V De Trinitate
Augustinus, De Trinitate, V, XXX
cum dicit quod non singulus in divinis sed Pater est dicens. Et sic conceditur illarum maior et negatur minor seu secunda pars antecedentis. Alio modo sumitur dicere pro perfecte intelligere et sic debet intelligi minor, et tunc nota non sequitur conclusio quia medium mutatur. Secundo posset dici quod non solum potest producit[?ere?] eo quod perfecte intelligit praecise sed eo quod perfectum intelligere est in ipso patre cum inclusione respectus[?] necessario requisiti ad Filium producendum qui respectus[?] est paternitas Filius autem et Spiritus Sanctus, licet intelligant, tamen illum respectum[?] non habent, ideo non generant per intelligere, sed sic dicendo est solvere idem per idem.

Ad septimum, dicitur sicut prius quod non sequitur licet 11[?n?] Spiritus Sanctus aeque perfecte diligat super Pater et Filius, tamen non habet illud diligere cum respectu[?] requisito necessario ad producendum Spiritum Sanctum qui est spiratio passiva activa quae opponitur spirationi passive quam Spiritus Sanctus habet vel est.

Ad primum contra tertiam conclusionem dicitur ad Ieromium quod ingenitum potest accipi tripliciter. Primo, pro illo qui non habet in se generationem passive sumptam. Secundo, pro illo qui non habet huius generationem. Tertio, pro illo qui non habet generationem nec est ab habente eam et cum hoc habet proprietatem oppositam tali generationi passive. Primo modo Spiritus Sanctus dicitur ingenitus quia non genitus et secundum hunc modum loquitur Ieromus. Secundo essentia divina dicitur ingentia. Tertio, modo solus Pater et isto modo loquitur conclusio.
Ad secundum dicitur Commentator loquitur de communicatione naturae creatae.

Ad 3m dicitur primo quod
so
ratio fundatur super falso. Primo, quia personae non solum relationibus oppositis distinguitur. Secundo, quia productiones divinae differunt se ipsis et non tantum relationibus, ideo nihil concludit ratio.
Ad primam rationem in oppositum patet per dictam in prima conclusione quia non sequitur quod possit viator scire, licet ita sit.
Ad secundum negatur consequentia.

Ad tertium patet ex tertia conclusione et solutione rationum contra eam quia Spiritus Sanctus potest dici ingenitus et improprie iuxta primum modum distinctionis ponente. Secundo posset negari illa consequentia est non genitus, igitur ingenitus sicut non sequitur hoc est non iustum, ergo iniustum quia de lapide. Antecedens est verum, et consequens falsum.

Item cum quaeritur. Lombardus, I, d. 12, c. 1, n. 1
Haec distinctio continet tres conclusiones. Prima: quod cum quaeritur utrum Spiritus Sanctus prius procedat a Patre quam a Filio, dicendum est quod qui potest intelligere generationem Filii de Patre sine tempore etiam sine tempore processionem Spiritus Sancti ab utroque a Patre et Filio intelligat quia in Trinitate nihil prius aut posterius quia ibi ex tempore nihil inchoatur.
Secunda conclusio: quod sicut Spiritus Sanctus non processit ante a Patre quam a Filio, ita non magis vel amplius vel plenius procedit a Patre quam a Filio.

Tertia conclusio: quod cum Augustinus dicit Spiritum Sanctum procedere a Patre principaliter et Ieromus dicit quod procedit a Patre proprie et Hilarius dicit quod Spiritus Sanctus mittitur a Patre per Filium et a Patre esse habet per Filium, debet sic intelligi quod Spiritus
Spiritus procedat a Patre hoc habet Patre a se quod autem procedat a Filio vel ab ipso mittatur hoc Filius habet a Patre quia Pater gignendo Filium dedat ei quod Spiritus Sanctus ab eo procedent et mitteretur.

Post haec considerandum est. Lombardus, I, d. 13, c. 1, n. 1
Haec 13 distinctio continet a conclusiones. Prima quod licet Spiritus Sanctus procedat a Patre et sit de substantia Patris sicut et Filius, non tamen dicitur natus sive genitus, et ideo non dicitur Filius cuius ratio est quia si diceretur Filius esset Filius Patris et Filii cum procedat ab utroque, sed absurdum est quod sit Filius amborum quia nullus est filius duorum nisi sit patris et matris.

Secunda conclusio: quod licet Filius et Spiritus Sanctus procedant a patre tamen dissimiliter quia Spiritus Sanctus procedit a Patre quomodo datus sive ut donum Filius vero procedit ut
d
natus sive ut genitus et ideo Spiritus Sanctus non est Filius.

Tertia conclusio: quod Spiritus Sanctus non dicitur Filius quia non est genitus sicut unigenitus nec factus ut per Dei gratiam in adoptionem nasceretur sicut et nos et sic diceretur Filius dei per adoptionem.
Quarta conclusio: quod non esse quod procedit nascitur quamvis omne quod nascitur procedat.

Quinta conclusio: quod inter verbi generationem et Spiritus Sancti processionem distinguere[?] non sufficimus in hac vita et ideo sufficiat cuilibet scire quod Filius non est a se ipso sed a Patre nec Spiritus Sanctus a se ipso sed procedit ab utroque.

Sexta conclusio: quod secundum Augustinum, Spiritus Sanctus non debet dici genitus nec ingenitus quia si genitus esset duo filii in divinis, si autem ingenitus duos patres ibi affirmaremus quod est inconveniens. Patet quia esse ingenitum proprie convenit Patri.

Septima conclusio: quod secundum Ieromium Spiritus Sanctus dicitur ingenitus, sed Ieromus accipit ingenitum pro non genito et sic potest concedi quod Spiritus Sanctus est ingenitus, id est non genitus. Augustinus vero accipit ingenitum quam illo qui ab alio non est aliquo, tamen alius est et sic accipiendo ingenitum de solo Patre dicitur quia Filius est ab alio et Spiritus Sanctus a Patre et Filio qui sunt aliae personae. Et sic Magister concordat dictam Augustini et Ieronimi, et haec sufficiant pro praesenti lectione.
